p: HAART optimism is the focus of many surveys designed to measure how risk perception evolves after introducing HIV interventions. HAART optimism is defined as a consequence of HAART that may lead to a change in behavior, such as an increase in unprotected sex, or a decreased likelihood to remain on medication. A number of studies have explored the existence of HAART optimism, and the factors that may drive its emergence. In terms of treatment commitment, one such study comprising of a mass questionnaire found that 57% of optimists reported not always taking their HAART, compared to 29% of the individuals characterized as pessimistic 13. The study authors concluded that treatment centres should more closely monitor patientsâ€™ prognostic beliefs.
